tool.name: configurerasterfields

param.name: inRaster
param.dialogReference: The raster that the tool will use to create the auxiliary file. This raster will become a layer in the mosaic dataset.
param.pythonReference: The raster that the tool will use to create the auxiliary file. This raster will become a layer in the mosaic dataset.

param.name: Title
param.dialogReference: The title that will display for this raster layer in the weighted overlay service.
param.pythonReference: The title that will display for this raster layer in the weighted overlay service.

param.name: Description
param.dialogReference: Description for this raster layer that will display when the info button is clicked in the weighted overlay service.
param.pythonReference: Description for this raster layer that will display when the info button is clicked in the weighted overlay service.

param.name: url
param.dialogReference: URL to a hosted image layer that will display when the preview button is clicked in the weighted overlay service. Use this field to provide a preview functionality for the raster layers in your weighted overlay service's mosaic dataset. You must share each raster layer that you want to preview as an image service.
param.pythonReference: URL to a hosted image layer that will display when the preview button is clicked in the weighted overlay service. Use this field to provide a preview functionality for the raster layers in your weighted overlay service's mosaic dataset. You must share each raster layer that you want to preview as an image service.

param.name: InputRanges
param.dialogReference: A comma-delimited string that defines a grouping of input raster cell values. These groups will be mapped to a suitability scale specified in the Output Values parameter. Groups are defined as ranges of min-inclusive, max-exclusive values. For example, if you have a raster with a value range of 0 – 100, you could classify the raster into 5 equal-interval groups: 0 – 20, 21 – 40, 41 – 60, 61 – 80, and 81 – 100. Your input range string would be 0,21,21,41,41,61,61,81,81,101. Remove any spaces between the values.
param.pythonReference: A comma-delimited string that defines a grouping of input raster cell values. These groups will be mapped to a suitability scale specified in the Output Values parameter. Groups are defined as ranges of min-inclusive, max-exclusive values. For example, if you have a raster with a value range of 0 – 100, you could classify the raster into 5 equal-interval groups: 0 – 20, 21 – 40, 41 – 60, 61 – 80, and 81 – 100. Your input range string would be 0,21,21,41,41,61,61,81,81,101. Remove any spaces between the values.

param.name: OutPutValues
param.dialogReference: A comma-delimited string that defines the suitability scale. These are values that the input ranges will be assigned by default in the app using the WRO service. These values can range from 0 – 9, and may reflect relative magnitude or importance of the input ranges. For the example above, where the raster with a range of 0 – 100 was grouped into five input ranges, the output ranges could be 1,3,5,7,9. This might indicate that the 81 – 100 range is the most important, and the 0 – 20 range least important. Note that there should always be half as many values in the Output Values field as there are in the Input Values field. These are just default numbers, the output values can always be changed in an app using the WRO service.
param.pythonReference: A comma-delimited string that defines the suitability scale. These are values that the input ranges will be assigned by default in the app using the WRO service. These values can range from 0 – 9, and may reflect relative magnitude or importance of the input ranges. For the example above, where the raster with a range of 0 – 100 was grouped into five input ranges, the output ranges could be 1,3,5,7,9. This might indicate that the 81 – 100 range is the most important, and the 0 – 20 range least important. Note that there should always be half as many values in the Output Values field as there are in the Input Values field. These are just default numbers, the output values can always be changed in an app using the WRO service.

param.name: NoDataRanges
param.dialogReference: A range of values that you want represented as NoData. For example, to map 0 values to No Data, you would type in 0,0.
param.pythonReference: A range of values that you want represented as NoData. For example, to map 0 values to No Data, you would type in 0,0.

param.name: RangeLabels
param.dialogReference: The labels for the Output Values. There should be the same number of Range Labels as there are Output Values. To use the example of the raster with values of 0 – 100 being grouped into 5 classes, you could label these classes Very Low,Low,Medium,High,Very High. Remove any spaces between the values.
param.pythonReference: The labels for the Output Values. There should be the same number of Range Labels as there are Output Values. To use the example of the raster with values of 0 – 100 being grouped into 5 classes, you could label these classes Very Low,Low,Medium,High,Very High. Remove any spaces between the values.

param.name: NoDataRangeLabels
param.dialogReference: A label for the NoData Range. For example: No Data. Required only if you have specified a NoData range.
param.pythonReference: A label for the NoData Range. For example: No Data. Required only if you have specified a NoData range.

tool.summary: Creates an auxiliary file that is used by the Build Mosaic Dataset tool to populate the fields of the mosaic dataset. This tool creates data that is inserted into specific fields in the mosaic dataset when you run the Build Mosaic Dataset tool. The data is stored in an auxiliary file associated with the input raster.

dataIdInfo.idAbs: Creates an auxiliary file that is used by the Build Mosaic Dataset tool to populate the fields of the mosaic dataset. This tool creates data that is inserted into specific fields in the mosaic dataset when you run the Build Mosaic Dataset tool. The data is stored in an auxiliary file associated with the input raster.
